Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 04:17PM - edited Jan 15, 2013 04:20PM by 4myangels Hi Everyone, I'm 43, married with two children aged 6 and 8. My kids are my angels and everything I do, including this fight, is for them. (hence my screen name). I'm a fairly typical suburban housewife, but at one point, before my kids were born, I had a successful career. I gave it up to spend more time with my kids and have had no regrets. I was diagnosed at age 42 with a single met to my spine. It's been hard for me to come to terms with having stage iv, incurable cancer mostly because I was aware of the lump in my breast for several years. I've always taken care of myself by eating really well, working out and going to the doctor every year for physicals and for anything else that came up. I even did regular self breast exams and every time I would say, "there's that darn cyst again!" My relatives have all lived until their nineties, so with no family history of any type of cancer and regular reassurances from multiple doctors that my lump was nothing "because it moves", I was fairly surprised to learn that it was in fact cancer. I always thought breast cancer was an old lady disease. Ha! Shortly after learning I had cancer, I had a PET/CT and found out I had a met on my spine. I was shocked and heartbroken. I always thought that even if I did have breast cancer, it was the good one to get. My husband is very supportive but I know he prefers to forget I have cancer. I don't complain to him and I try to stay as positive as I can around him because I know it just makes things easier for everyone. I am so grateful for these boards because I feel I have the freedom to express my worries, sadness and anger and all of you have been so welcoming, understanding and forgiving. My job as a mother is to do everything I can to prepare my children for the world. I hope every day that I can see them grow up, but I also understand how uncertain my prognosis is. I've been cramming a lot in, giving them a lifetime of love now and no longer thinking "I'll do that with them when they get older." It's either now or never.

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2012 07:07AM 4myangels wrote: I thought I'd add my 2 cents since I just had this done. For me, there were several reasons to do it. First, I'm 43 and done having kids. Second, I was getting a Zoladex shot every 28 days and that sucker hurt going in. Third, it was fairly easy although it was my first surgery of any kind so I don't have anything to compare it to. I was feeling not so great for 2 days and that was it. I can't lift anything more than 10 lbs for 4-6 weeks so I've kept my physical activities to a minimum. As far as the effects of menopause, I haven't noticed much of a difference except for a few more night sweats. I was already getting hot flashes before the surgery. If you're already getting hot flashes, I wouldn't worry about being thrown into menopause. You're already there, hon. The other thing I want to add, is that I noticed the lump in my breast get smaller after the surgery. My onc thinks I'm crazy because I was getting zoladex and that's supposed to be the same thing. However, I did notice a difference. So for me, I feel the complete removal of my estrogen factory was better than shutting them down chemically. I'm not sure if anyone else had this experience. It could very well all be in my head.

Posts.Content: 4myangels wrote: Many years ago I remember watching an Oprah segment about a beautiful young mom with Stage iv breast cancer who left behind a bunch of video tapes for her daughter. Her daughter was young at the time she died, but she filled the tapes with all sorts of motherly advice her daughter would need later in life (how to wear make-up, how to deal with boys, what if her father gets remarried perhaps, etc.) since she wouldn't be there herself to help her daughter. She also bought a bunch of charms for her daughter to make a charm bracelet and her daughter opened one on each of her birthdays. I never really watched Oprah, but I did happen to see this one episode. I cried and cried when I saw it, not realizing I would be in that position myself many years later. (my kids are now 6 and 7) So, my question is, what should I do for my kids? I'm not really a video person. I could write letters, put together photo albums, etc., but would they want this? It would take a lot of time, and I'll do it if it provides them comfort, but maybe they'll just want to get on with their lives. I just don't know. I kind of hoping to hear from people who lost a parent when they were young or knows someone who did. Did they leave anything for you? Did it help you? Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 02:57PM 4myangels wrote: I had 4 doctors tell me they didn't think my lymph nodes were involved, but since I didn't have surgery we don't know for sure. Somehow a rogue cell broke off and got out. It doesn't really matter how it happened. I too thought I was stage 2 until I had a PET/CT before surgery. I didn't have any symptoms but my surgeon was just being cautious. It showed a small spot on my spine so I had an MRI of lumbar region. Then, I had a bone biopsy to confirm what they suspected. Surgery was cancelled and I started treatment soon after. Since my primary tumor is still there, my doctor can determine if the treatment is working. So far, it's shrinking, so that's a good sign. Follow-up scans will be used as well to check for progression. There are many others who have doing this a lot longer than me so hopefully they will have some useful insights as well.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 09:33AM - edited Jan 24, 2013 09:37AM by 4myangels KSkier, I admire you for your fortitude, but I agree with Divine. You'll only inflate your doctor's ego. I think I'd be feeling too vulnerable wearing nothing but a paper gown in a tiny exam room telling someone they ruined my life. I'll be due for another annual gyn visit soon and I can assure you I will be going somewhere else. In fact, I just got a postcard from my gyn as a reminder and I called her office telling them never to contact me again. As you may remember, I too was grossly misdiagnosed for years by three different doctors. In my case I had a lump which was ignored by a doctor all throughout my 30's. I starting screening at 40 but it came back negative. Same thing at age 41. I stupidly believed those doctors who told me it was nothing. I was on hormonal birth control the entire time too! At 42, my lump was finally big enough to show up on the mammo. That's when my world fell apart. I too am angry and pissed. Since I was diagnosed, I ordered all my medical records to figure out what the hell happened. I was horrified when I saw that the doctors simply scribbled down that I had "fibrocystic breasts" even though I had specific conversations with them about my lump. There was no mention about the lump in any of my radiology reports either, and since nothing was written down in my medical records, there was no way to cross-check. I truly believe that any of the 3 doctors who misdiagnosed me could have saved me. However, I've only dealt with the 3rd one so far. For doctor #3, I had my primary care physician call up her office and let her know I was stage IV. My PCP had just lost her own sister to breast cancer so she was the right one to chew out my GYN. My GYN now thinks I'm suing her (I'm not, but I'm going to let her worry about it until the statute of limitations runs out.) I'm still trying to figure out what to tell doctors #1 and #2. I will probably write them letters, but I'm just not ready yet. What angers me so much about my situation is the fact that I had an obvious lump yet my screening tests came back negative. Doctors don't understand how unreliable mammograms can be and that's just wrong. If doctors don't understand how unreliable they are, how are we, as patients, supposed to understand? Even when I was finally told "it's probably cancer" based on a breast MRI, I asked my doctor if it was early stage. She said, "as long as you got your mammogram last year." What an idiot. If I didn't have small children, I would be writing blogs, articles, books and whatever else to tell the world how useless screening is for some women and how stupid some doctors are. But, my disease will already take so much away from my precious kids, I don't want them growing up thinking something could have been done to save me. I do know that since my primary care physician called doctor #3, they have changed the way they do things in their office. I don't have specifics, but I do know they are more careful now. I suppose I'm pleased with that. So maybe whatever you decide to do, try to approach it that way. As awful as our situations are, maybe somehow we can save someone else from going through this. I hope this helps and I'm sorry if this turned into a rant just about me.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2012 01:28PM - edited Oct 22, 2012 01:32PM by 4myangels I have some strong feelings about all this pink stuff and haven't held back in posting my opinions about all the celebrating that goes on this month. Just watching a professional football game these days makes my stomach churn. Seriously, how are pink cleats made in China going to save my life? However, I'm glad that so much attention is being given to breast cancer. In 2011, Komen raised $475 million, the BCRF around $40 million and Avon raised around $50 million. That's over a half billion dollars in one year going to just these three charities. There are over 1000 breast cancer charities out there, so the total amount raised in the name of breast cancer is even higher. Pancreatic cancer, colon cancer, lung cancer, etc. are deadly cancers too, but don't get anywhere near this amount. The fundamental problem with pinktober is very little money is going to research and people don't know this. Komen is especially guilty of this given how big a piece of the fundraising pie they own. They give somewhere around 15% to research, including less than 2% to resesarch for metastatic breast cancer. This needs to change. Then there are all the companies that ride the pink wave by selling products with pink ribbons. They are using the disease to make money. This is wrong on so many levels. New laws have just been instituted requiring companies that engage in cause marketing to disclose exactly how much goes to breast cancer charities. This is a step in the right direction, but more needs to be done. So, given how much money the pink stuff has raised, in some ways, I'm actually OK with the pink. My sister made pink ribbon magnets for me and everyone in my family. The ribbons won't help find a cure for me, but it's her way of showing she cares and everytime I see it I will be reminded of that. Anyone who sends me a pink ecard, donates to breast cancer charities or walks on my behalf is doing the same thing: showing they care. These gestures don't bother me. In fact, I'm honored and touched by them. What bothers me is the fact that so much time and money is spent on pink stuff yet so little is going to actually finding a cure. There are so many well-meaning people out there who only want to help us live longer but who have been totally deceived by charities like Komen and the companies selling pink crap. I really wish more of this well-intended money would go to research.
Posts.Title: Pinktober TonyaB 4myangels

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 11:44AM 4myangels wrote: Could this be the article? http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/doublex/2012/12/are_mammograms_useless_new_england_journal_of_medicine_article_claims_they.html The article asks the question "Are Mammograms Useless?" It goes on to say  that mammograms overdiagnose breast cancer because they catch so many early cancers that probably would have never turned into anything anyway. Well, a mammogram didn't find my cancer until I was stage 4. The one I had a year before I was diagnosed and the one the year before that were both negative. I also had screening ultrasounds and they were negative too. So, in my case, yes, mammograms were useless, but not for the reasons stated in the article. I really think someone ought to look at the flip side and write about all the cancers mammograms can miss. I certainly wish I knew about the limitations of mammograms. Probably would have saved my life.
